Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: EAGER: Leveraging Advanced Cyberinfrastructure and Developing Organizational Resilience for NSF Large Facilities in the Pandemic Era

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
The COVID-19 global pandemic in 2020 has created major disruptions to the research enterprise. NSF-supported large facilities are critical elements of US research infrastructure and are increasingly dependent on advanced cyberinfrastructure (CI) – comprising advanced computing, data and software assets, networking, and the related specialized workforce – to accomplish their science missions. This study investigates how large facilities are impacted by, and are responding to, the pandemic challenge with a focus on understanding factors related to the use of existing CI. This project will also explore the value of CI in the broader social context of how people and the facilities perceive and respond to major disruptive events. The goal is to determine how to design large facility organizations to be more resilient during crises and major disasters and what CI capabilities are needed to support these and other large science projects to accomplish their science missions during such disruptions.

This study comprises three main research questions related to NSF large facilities and CI during the pandemic: (a) What types of research activities remain "business as usual" and what types of activities must adapt or stop completely under pandemic conditions? (b) If facilities could turn back time, what would they have done to better prepare? And (c) What lessons are facilities learning from the current disruptions, and how can these be best disseminated to the facility, CI, and research communities? The approach is grounded in Weick's Theory of Organizing, and examines disruptions from the environment (ecological change) through the stages of enactment (immediate actions), selection (rules establishment), and retention (identification of approaches worth re-utilizing in future events), with feedback loops linking the stages and the environment. The project’s goals will be accomplished primarily through interviews with domain scientists, CI users, developers, and administrators who are engaged in NSF large facility science and operations. The project will also analyze and document the organizational structures of the facilities to identify the key engagement points with national CI resources and services, towards enhancing the ability of the broader CI community to engage with the facilities. The ultimate objective of this project is to provide a framework for facilities and other large science projects to mitigate disruptions to their scientific and operational activities in current and future times of crisis. Study outcomes and findings will be widely disseminated to the stakeholder communities.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This study examined how science organizations (i.e., NSF funded major facilities/MFs, such as Academic Research Fleets, National Radio Astronomy Observatory, Large Hadron Collider; see https://new.nsf.gov/focus-areas/infrastructure) responded to the pandemic, and how they leveraged communication technologies and advanced cyberinfrastructure to keep their work and science mission in operation during the shutdowns and stay-at-home orders.  

Overall, study findings show that pandemic responses are based on strategies (e.g., promote flexibility, encourage information sharing, create alignments, sensitize team to risk, and keep work going despite challenges) and mindsets (vulnerability awareness, no science is an island mentality, socio-technical perspective, personal-professional integration, and adaptation readiness).

 

To further elaborate on the strategy of promoting flexibility, another analysis shows that MF re-organized work during the pandemic based on 10 practices (with quantitative agreement scores and in ranked order): (1) Change work expectations to consider colleagues’ personal/family needs (4.68/5), (2) Provide flexibility for workers to focus on quality and quantity of work, and not where they do the work (4.44/5), (3) Reach out to peers in other facilities/organizations for ideas, strategies, and best practices (4.44/5), (4) Do what you can, when you can (4.18/5), (5) Have a master scheduler/ project management platform to keep track of all the tasks and who is doing what (4.12/5), (6) Get used to delays, changes, uncertainty, and feeling overwhelmed (4.10/5), (7) Schedule virtual meetings strictly, to create a team arrangement for workers not to miss a meeting due to interruptions/chaos at home, etc. (3.94/5), (8) Actively use nonverbal cues to make online meetings engaging (3.79/5), (9) Form a committee/taskforce to collect input and explore solutions across multiple levels in the organization (3.79/5), and (10) Set up social platforms for workers to interact informally (3.48/5). Overall, we observed that all 10 strategies aimed at leveraging communication to keep the workplace coordinated virtually.

 

In a third analysis, we found that during decision-making, MFs tend to turn to supervisors, health authorities, and their institutions/universities for pandemic related information, but they tend to make decisions and policies based on risk assessments, input from teams, and triangulating information from multiple sources. In other words, the decision-making methods (e.g., risk assessment) do not always match their information sources (e.g., supervisors).

 

Beyond the findings reported above, the study has some larger implications. The study design was grounded in an organizational communication theory of sense-making. The study findings so far suggest to extend the scope of sense making beyond the traditional organizational boundaries. For example, participants talked about the need for communicating with multiple organizations (e.g., hosting universities, sponsoring agencies, peer organizations) for information and ideas during the pandemic. This finding suggests an ecosystem view (rather than a single organizational view) on how groups and teams make sense of crisis information. This is a perspective not prominent in the current literature.

 

Second, while organizations (including MFs) strive to maintain fairness and consistency in how they managed the pandemic with workers and employees, findings from this study suggest that “one size does not fit all” and flexibility is the best practice during a crisis, when sense-making is dynamic and ongoing. This may remain a tension in practice because what the organizations think is best to do (e.g., fairness and consistency) runs contrary to what is practically achievable (i.e., one size practically does not fit all).

 

Finally, the study further emphasizes some insights already known, but often overlooked in organizations. First, while the pandemic was a medical science crisis, human communication is key to effective crisis management and sense-making (individual and organizational). Second, when work has to go online, again, human communication is key to keeping the operation and science mission going. In other words, communication is constitutive of organizations and virtual work. Third, just because everyone communicates, it does not make everyone a good communicator (similar to the observation that because everyone drives, it does not make everyone a good driver). However, during a crisis, the context in which effective communication is necessary reveals it to be a key organizational weakness. This is problematic because communication skills are not always valued as much as technical skills, especially in technical organizations and the scientific workplace. This finding is not revolutionary, but it is important to note that what matters is the actual implementation, which is often weak or suboptimal. We conclude that effective organizational communication is a skillset that needs to be intentionally trained and promoted at workplaces on a regular basis, including MFs.
